text: We propose the first probabilistic approach to modeling cross-lingual semantic similarity ( CLSS ) in context which requires only comparable data .

The approach relies on an idea of projecting words and sets of words into a shared latent semantic space spanned by language-pair independent latent semantic concepts ( e.g. , cross-lingual topics obtained by a multilingual topic model ) .
text_parent: We present new models that modulate the isolated out-of-context word representations with contextual knowledge .

text: These latent cross-lingual concepts are induced from a comparable corpus without any additional lexical resources .
text_parent: The approach relies on an idea of projecting words and sets of words into a shared latent semantic space spanned by language-pair independent latent semantic concepts ( e.g. , cross-lingual topics obtained by a multilingual topic model ) .

text: Word meaning is represented as a probability distribution over the latent concepts , and a change in meaning is represented as a change in the distribution over these latent concepts .
text_parent: These latent cross-lingual concepts are induced from a comparable corpus without any additional lexical resources .

text: We present new models that modulate the isolated out-of-context word representations with contextual knowledge .

text: Results on the task of suggesting word translations in context for 3 language pairs reveal the utility of the proposed contextualized models of cross-lingual semantic similarity .

text: The current approaches to Semantic Role Labeling ( SRL ) usually perform role classification for each predicate separately and the interaction among individual predicate's role labeling is ignored if there is more than one predicate in a sentence .

text: Word-sense recognition and disambiguation ( WERD ) is the task of identifying word phrases and their senses in natural language text .
text_parent: Though it is well understood how to disambiguate noun phrases , this task is much less studied for verbs and verbal phrases .

text: Though it is well understood how to disambiguate noun phrases , this task is much less studied for verbs and verbal phrases .
text_parent: We present Werdy , a framework for WERD with particular focus on verbs and verbal phrases .

text: We present Werdy , a framework for WERD with particular focus on verbs and verbal phrases .
Our framework first identifies multi-word expressions based on the syntactic structure of the sentence ; this allows us to recognize both contiguous and non-contiguous phrases .
text_parent: We present Werdy , a framework for WERD with particular focus on verbs and verbal phrases .

text: We then generate a list of candidate senses for each word or phrase , using novel syntactic and semantic pruning techniques .
text_parent: Our framework first identifies multi-word expressions based on the syntactic structure of the sentence ; this allows us to recognize both contiguous and non-contiguous phrases .

text: We also construct and leverage a new resource of pairs of senses for verbs and their object arguments .
text_parent: Our framework first identifies multi-word expressions based on the syntactic structure of the sentence ; this allows us to recognize both contiguous and non-contiguous phrases .

text: Finally , we feed the so-obtained candidate senses into standard word-sense disambiguation ( WSD ) methods , and boost their precision and recall .
text_parent: We then generate a list of candidate senses for each word or phrase , using novel syntactic and semantic pruning techniques .

text: Our experiments indicate that Werdy significantly increases the performance of existing WSD methods .

text: Language is given meaning through its correspondence with a world representation .

text: Much work in recent years has gone into the construction of large knowledge bases ( KBs ) , such as Freebase , DBPedia , NELL , and YAGO .
text_parent: Prior work has shown how to make use of a large text corpus to augment random walk inference over KBs .

text: While these KBs are very large , they are still very incomplete , necessitating the use of inference to fill in gaps .
text_parent: We present two improvements to the use of such large corpora to augment KB inference .

text: Prior work has shown how to make use of a large text corpus to augment random walk inference over KBs .
text_parent: While these KBs are very large , they are still very incomplete , necessitating the use of inference to fill in gaps .

text: We present two improvements to the use of such large corpora to augment KB inference .
First , we present a new technique for combining KB relations and surface text into a single graph representation that is much more compact than graphs used in prior work .
text_parent: We present two improvements to the use of such large corpora to augment KB inference .

text: Second , we describe how to incorporate vector space similarity into random walk inference over KBs , reducing the feature sparsity inherent in using surface text .
text_parent: First , we present a new technique for combining KB relations and surface text into a single graph representation that is much more compact than graphs used in prior work .

text: This allows us to combine distributional similarity with symbolic logical inference in novel and effective ways .
text_parent: Second , we describe how to incorporate vector space similarity into random walk inference over KBs , reducing the feature sparsity inherent in using surface text .

text: With experiments on many relations from two separate KBs , we show that our methods significantly outperform prior work on KB inference , both in the size of problem our methods can handle and in the quality of predictions made .
text_parent: We present two improvements to the use of such large corpora to augment KB inference .

text: State-of-the-art semantic role labelling systems require large annotated corpora to achieve full performance .

text: In this paper , we mitigate both of these problems by employing distributional word representations gathered from unlabelled data .

text: This paper reports on the development of a hybrid and simple method based on a machine learning classifier ( Naive Bayes ) , Word Sense Disambiguation and rules , for the automatic assignment of WordNet Domains to nominal entries of a lexicographic dictionary , the Senso Comune De Mauro Lexicon .

text: We introduce a Semantic Role Labeling ( SRL ) parser that finds semantic roles for a predicate together with the syntactic paths linking predicates and arguments .

Our main contribution is to formulate SRL in terms of shortest-path inference , on the assumption that the SRL model is restricted to arc-factored features of the syntactic paths behind semantic roles .
text_parent: We introduce a Semantic Role Labeling ( SRL ) parser that finds semantic roles for a predicate together with the syntactic paths linking predicates and arguments .

text: Overall , our method for SRL is a novel way to exploit larger variability in the syntactic realizations of predicate-argument relations , moving away from pipeline architectures .
text_parent: Our main contribution is to formulate SRL in terms of shortest-path inference , on the assumption that the SRL model is restricted to arc-factored features of the syntactic paths behind semantic roles .

text: Experiments show that our approach improves the robustness of the predictions , producing arc-factored models that perform closely to methods using unrestricted features from the syntax .

text: We present an empirical study on the use of semantic information for Concept Segmentation and Labeling ( CSL ) , which is an important step for semantic parsing .

We represent the alternative analyses output by a state-of-the-art CSL parser with tree structures , which we rerank with a classifier trained on two types of semantic tree kernels : one processing structures built with words , concepts and Brown clusters , and another one using semantic similarity among the words composing the structure .
text_parent: We present an empirical study on the use of semantic information for Concept Segmentation and Labeling ( CSL ) , which is an important step for semantic parsing .

text: The results on a corpus from the restaurant domain show that our semantic kernels exploiting similarity measures outperform state-of-the-art rerankers .

text: This paper introduces a model of multiple-instance learning applied to the prediction of aspect ratings or judgments of specific properties of an item from user-contributed texts such as product reviews .
Each variable-length text is represented by several independent feature vectors ; one word vector per sentence or paragraph .
text_parent: This paper introduces a model of multiple-instance learning applied to the prediction of aspect ratings or judgments of specific properties of an item from user-contributed texts such as product reviews .

text: For learning from texts with known aspect ratings , the model performs multiple-instance regression ( MIR ) and assigns importance weights to each of the sentences or paragraphs of a text , uncovering their contribution to the aspect ratings .
text_parent: Each variable-length text is represented by several independent feature vectors ; one word vector per sentence or paragraph .

text: Next , the model is used to predict aspect ratings in previously unseen texts , demonstrating interpretability and explanatory power for its predictions .
text_parent: For learning from texts with known aspect ratings , the model performs multiple-instance regression ( MIR ) and assigns importance weights to each of the sentences or paragraphs of a text , uncovering their contribution to the aspect ratings .

text: We evaluate the model on seven multi-aspect sentiment analysis data sets , improving over four MIR baselines and two strong bag-of-words linear models , namely SVR and Lasso , by more than 10 % relative in terms of MSE .
text_parent: This paper introduces a model of multiple-instance learning applied to the prediction of aspect ratings or judgments of specific properties of an item from user-contributed texts such as product reviews .

text: We propose a semi-supervised bootstrapping algorithm for analyzing China's foreign relations from the People's Daily .
text_parent: Our approach addresses sentiment target clustering , subjective lexicons extraction and sentiment prediction in a unified framework .

text: In this paper , we propose a joint segmentation and classification framework for sentiment analysis .

Existing sentiment classification algorithms typically split a sentence as a word sequence , which does not effectively handle the inconsistent sentiment polarity between a phrase and the words it contains , such as " not bad"  and " a great deal of " .
text_parent: In this paper , we propose a joint segmentation and classification framework for sentiment analysis .

text: We address this issue by developing a joint segmentation and classification framework ( JSC ) , which simultaneously conducts sentence segmentation and sentence-level sentiment classification .
text_parent: In this paper , we propose a joint segmentation and classification framework for sentiment analysis .

text: Specifically , we use a log-linear model to score each segmentation candidate , and exploit the phrasal information of top-ranked segmentations as features to build the sentiment classifier .
text_parent: We address this issue by developing a joint segmentation and classification framework ( JSC ) , which simultaneously conducts sentence segmentation and sentence-level sentiment classification .

text: A marginal log-likelihood objective function is devised for the segmentation model , which is optimized for enhancing the sentiment classification performance .

text: The joint model is trained only based on the annotated sentiment polarity of sentences , without any segmentation annotations .

text: Experiments on a benchmark Twitter sentiment classification dataset in SemEval 2013 show that , our joint model performs comparably with the state-of-the-art methods .

text: Shell nouns , such as fact and problem , occur frequently in all kinds of texts .
text_parent: These nouns themselves are unspecific , and can only be interpreted together with the shell content .

text: These nouns themselves are unspecific , and can only be interpreted together with the shell content .
text_parent: We propose a general approach to automatically identify shell content of shell nouns .

text: We propose a general approach to automatically identify shell content of shell nouns .
Our approach exploits lexico-syntactic knowledge derived from the linguistics literature .
text_parent: We propose a general approach to automatically identify shell content of shell nouns .

text: We evaluate the approach on a variety of shell nouns with a variety of syntactic expectations , achieving accuracies in the range of 62 % ( baseline = 33 % ) to 83 % ( baseline = 74 % ) on crowd-annotated data .
text_parent: We propose a general approach to automatically identify shell content of shell nouns .

text: We present a comparison of different selectional preference models and evaluate them on an automatic verb classification task in German .

text: A very simple model based on lexical preferences is also found to perform well .

text: This paper presents a novel approach to learning to solve simple arithmetic word problems .

text: Common-sense reasoning is important for AI applications , both in NLP and many vision and robotics tasks .
text_parent: We propose NaturalLI : a Natural Logic inference system for inferring common sense facts - for instance , that cats have tails or tomatoes are round - from a very large database of known facts .

text: We propose NaturalLI : a Natural Logic inference system for inferring common sense facts - for instance , that cats have tails or tomatoes are round - from a very large database of known facts .
In addition to being able to provide strictly valid derivations , the system is also able to produce derivations which are only likely valid , accompanied by an associated confidence .
text_parent: We propose NaturalLI : a Natural Logic inference system for inferring common sense facts - for instance , that cats have tails or tomatoes are round - from a very large database of known facts .

text: We both show that our system is able to capture strict Natural Logic inferences on the FraCaS test suite , and demonstrate its ability to predict common sense facts with 49 % recall and 91 % precision .
text_parent: We propose NaturalLI : a Natural Logic inference system for inferring common sense facts - for instance , that cats have tails or tomatoes are round - from a very large database of known facts .

text: Term translation is of great importance for statistical machine translation ( SMT ) , especially document-informed SMT .
text_parent: In this paper , we investigate three issues of term translation in the context of document-informed SMT and propose three corresponding models : ( a ) a term translation disambiguation model which selects desirable translations for terms in the source language with domain information , ( b ) a term translation consistency model that encourages consistent translations for terms with a high strength of translation consistency throughout a document , and ( c ) a term bracketing model that rewards translation hypotheses where bracketable source terms are translated as a whole unit .

text: In this paper , we investigate three issues of term translation in the context of document-informed SMT and propose three corresponding models : ( a ) a term translation disambiguation model which selects desirable translations for terms in the source language with domain information , ( b ) a term translation consistency model that encourages consistent translations for terms with a high strength of translation consistency throughout a document , and ( c ) a term bracketing model that rewards translation hypotheses where bracketable source terms are translated as a whole unit .
We integrate the three models into hierarchical phrase-based SMT and evaluate their effectiveness on NIST Chinese-English translation tasks with large-scale training data .
text_parent: In this paper , we investigate three issues of term translation in the context of document-informed SMT and propose three corresponding models : ( a ) a term translation disambiguation model which selects desirable translations for terms in the source language with domain information , ( b ) a term translation consistency model that encourages consistent translations for terms with a high strength of translation consistency throughout a document , and ( c ) a term bracketing model that rewards translation hypotheses where bracketable source terms are translated as a whole unit .

text: Experiment results show that all three models can achieve significant improvements over the baseline .
text_parent: In this paper , we investigate three issues of term translation in the context of document-informed SMT and propose three corresponding models : ( a ) a term translation disambiguation model which selects desirable translations for terms in the source language with domain information , ( b ) a term translation consistency model that encourages consistent translations for terms with a high strength of translation consistency throughout a document , and ( c ) a term bracketing model that rewards translation hypotheses where bracketable source terms are translated as a whole unit .

text: Additionally , we can obtain a further improvement when combining the three models .
text_parent: Experiment results show that all three models can achieve significant improvements over the baseline .

text: Inspired by previous work , where decipherment is used to improve machine translation , we propose a new idea to combine word alignment and decipherment into a single learning process .

text: Phrase-based models directly trained on mix-of-domain corpora can be sub-optimal.
text_parent: In this paper we equip phrase-based models with a latent domain variable and present a novel method for adapting them to an in-domain task represented by a seed corpus .

text: In this paper we equip phrase-based models with a latent domain variable and present a novel method for adapting them to an in-domain task represented by a seed corpus .
We derive an EM algorithm which alternates between inducing domain-focused phrase pair estimates , and weights for mix-domain sentence pairs reflecting their relevance for the in-domain task .
text_parent: In this paper we equip phrase-based models with a latent domain variable and present a novel method for adapting them to an in-domain task represented by a seed corpus .

text: By embedding our latent domain phrase model in a sentence-level model and training the two in tandem , we are able to adapt all core translation components together - phrase , lexical and reordering .
text_parent: We derive an EM algorithm which alternates between inducing domain-focused phrase pair estimates , and weights for mix-domain sentence pairs reflecting their relevance for the in-domain task .

text: We show experiments on weighing sentence pairs for relevance as well as adapting phrase-based models , showing significant performance improvement in both tasks .
text_parent: In this paper we equip phrase-based models with a latent domain variable and present a novel method for adapting them to an in-domain task represented by a seed corpus .

text: In Corpus-Based Machine Translation , the search space of the translation candidates for a given input sentence is often defined by a set of ( cycle-free ) context-free grammar rules .
text_parent: We propose a natural extension to this representation by using lattice-rules that allow to easily encode an exponential number of variations of each rules .

text: This happens naturally in Syntax-Based Machine Translation and Hierarchical Phrase-Based Machine Translation ( where the representation will be the set of the target-side half of the synchronous rules used to parse the input sentence ) .
text_parent: In Corpus-Based Machine Translation , the search space of the translation candidates for a given input sentence is often defined by a set of ( cycle-free ) context-free grammar rules .

text: But it is also possible to describe Phrase-Based Machine Translation in this framework .
text_parent: This happens naturally in Syntax-Based Machine Translation and Hierarchical Phrase-Based Machine Translation ( where the representation will be the set of the target-side half of the synchronous rules used to parse the input sentence ) .

text: We propose a natural extension to this representation by using lattice-rules that allow to easily encode an exponential number of variations of each rules .
We also demonstrate how the representation of the search space has an impact on decoding efficiency , and how it is possible to optimize this representation .
text_parent: We propose a natural extension to this representation by using lattice-rules that allow to easily encode an exponential number of variations of each rules .

text: When documents and queries are presented in different languages , the common approach is to translate the query into the document language .
text_parent: While there are a variety of query translation approaches , recent research suggests that combining multiple methods into a single "structured query" is the most effective .

text: While there are a variety of query translation approaches , recent research suggests that combining multiple methods into a single "structured query" is the most effective .

text: In this paper , we introduce a novel approach for producing a unique combination recipe for each query , as it has also been shown that the optimal combination weights differ substantially across queries and other task specifics .
Our query-specific combination method generates statistically significant improvements over other combination strategies presented in the literature , such as uniform and task-specific weighting .

text: A major challenge in document clustering research arises from the growing amount of text data written in different languages .
text_parent: Previous approaches depend on language-specific solutions ( e.g. , bilingual dictionaries , sequential machine translation ) to evaluate document similarities , and the required transformations may alter the original document semantics .

text: Previous approaches depend on language-specific solutions ( e.g. , bilingual dictionaries , sequential machine translation ) to evaluate document similarities , and the required transformations may alter the original document semantics .
text_parent: To cope with this issue we propose a new document clustering approach for multilingual corpora that ( i ) exploits a large-scale multilingual knowledge base , ( ii ) takes advantage of the multi-topic nature of the text documents , and ( iii ) employs a tensor-based model to deal with high dimensionality and sparseness .

text: To cope with this issue we propose a new document clustering approach for multilingual corpora that ( i ) exploits a large-scale multilingual knowledge base , ( ii ) takes advantage of the multi-topic nature of the text documents , and ( iii ) employs a tensor-based model to deal with high dimensionality and sparseness .
Results have shown the significance of our approach and its better performance w.r.t. classic document clustering approaches , in both a balanced and an unbalanced corpus evaluation .
text_parent: To cope with this issue we propose a new document clustering approach for multilingual corpora that ( i ) exploits a large-scale multilingual knowledge base , ( ii ) takes advantage of the multi-topic nature of the text documents , and ( iii ) employs a tensor-based model to deal with high dimensionality and sparseness .

text: In this paper we examine the lexical substitution task for the medical domain .
We adapt the current best system from the open domain , which trains a single classifier for all instances using delexicalized features .
text_parent: In this paper we examine the lexical substitution task for the medical domain .

text: We show significant improvements over a strong baseline coming from a distributional thesaurus ( DT ) .
text_parent: In this paper we examine the lexical substitution task for the medical domain .

text: Whereas in the open domain system , features derived from WordNet show only slight improvements , we show that its counterpart for the medical domain ( UMLS ) shows a significant additional benefit when used for feature generation .
text_parent: We show significant improvements over a strong baseline coming from a distributional thesaurus ( DT ) .

text: This paper presents a system which learns to answer questions on a broad range of topics from a knowledge base using few hand-crafted features .
Our model learns low-dimensional embeddings of words and knowledge base constituents ; these representations are used to score natural language questions against candidate answers .
text_parent: This paper presents a system which learns to answer questions on a broad range of topics from a knowledge base using few hand-crafted features .

text: Training our system using pairs of questions and structured representations of their answers , and pairs of question paraphrases , yields competitive results on a recent benchmark of the literature .
text_parent: This paper presents a system which learns to answer questions on a broad range of topics from a knowledge base using few hand-crafted features .

text: Keyboard layout errors and homoglyphs in cross-language queries impact our ability to correctly interpret user information needs and offer relevant results .
text_parent: We present a machine learning approach to correcting these errors , based largely on character-level n-gram features .

text: We present a machine learning approach to correcting these errors , based largely on character-level n-gram features .
We demonstrate superior performance over rule-based methods , as well as a significant reduction in the number of queries that yield null search results .
text_parent: We present a machine learning approach to correcting these errors , based largely on character-level n-gram features .

text: Non-linear mappings of the form P ( ngram )  andlog ( 1+P ( ngram )) log ( 1+ ) are applied to the n-gram probabilities in five trainable open-source language identifiers .

The first mapping reduces classification errors by 4.0 % to 83.9 % over a test set of more than one million 65-character strings in 1366 languages , and by 2.6 % to 76.7 % over a subset of 781 languages .
text_parent: Non-linear mappings of the form P ( ngram )  andlog ( 1+P ( ngram )) log ( 1+ ) are applied to the n-gram probabilities in five trainable open-source language identifiers .

text: The second mapping improves four of the five identifiers by 10.6 % to 83.8 % on the larger corpus and 14.4 % to 76.7 % on the smaller corpus .
text_parent: The first mapping reduces classification errors by 4.0 % to 83.9 % over a test set of more than one million 65-character strings in 1366 languages , and by 2.6 % to 76.7 % over a subset of 781 languages .

text: The subset corpus and the modified programs are made freely available for download at http : //www.cs.cmu.edu/ralf/langid.html .
